name: Cordoba
fun_fact: Fun fact: Cordoba hosts 'The White Night of Flamenco' - an all-night citywide flamenco festival unique in the world. Also, the Mezquita-Cathedral is an architectural impossibility: an 8th-century mosque with a 16th-century Renaissance cathedral built right in the middle, creating one of history's most unusual buildings.

hero_dishes.name: Salmorejo
hero_dishes.description: Thick, creamy cold tomato soup blended with bread, garlic, olive oil, and sherry vinegar - topped with jam贸n and hard-boiled egg
hero_dishes.origin_story: Salmorejo is Cordoba's answer to gazpacho, but thicker and richer. Farm workers created it using stale bread, ripe tomatoes, and olive oil - ingredients always available in Andalusia. The bread makes it creamy without dairy. The jam贸n and egg toppings add protein. Perfect for blazing Cordoban summers when temperatures hit 45掳C (113掳F).
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional tabernas throughout Cordoba's historic center, near the Mezquita, or at tapas bars in the Jewish Quarter

hero_dishes.name: Flamenqu铆n
hero_dishes.description: Pork loin wrapped around jam贸n serrano and cheese, rolled, breaded, and deep-fried golden - served sliced to show the spiral
hero_dishes.origin_story: This hefty Cordoban specialty resembles a large croquette. The name means 'little flamenco' possibly because the spiral inside looks like a flamenco dancer's ruffled dress when sliced. It's protein-packed comfort food, invented when Cordobans wrapped leftover pork around jam贸n scraps. Now it's a point of local pride.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Cordoban taverns, tapas bars in the Jewish Quarter, or restaurants near the Mezquita

hero_dishes.name: Rabo de Toro (Oxtail Stew)
hero_dishes.description: Bull's tail slow-braised in red wine with vegetables until the meat falls off the bone - rich, gelatinous, deeply savory
hero_dishes.origin_story: Cordoba's bullfighting tradition created this dish - using the toro's tail after corridas (bullfights). The meat is tough, requiring hours of slow cooking. The result is intensely flavorful, almost like French boeuf bourguignon. Locals eat it during Feria de C贸rdoba (May fair week) and at traditional taverns year-round.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Cordoban restaurants, especially during Feria de C贸rdoba week in late May

hero_dishes.name: Berenjenas con Miel (Fried Eggplant with Honey)
hero_dishes.description: Thin slices of eggplant fried crispy, drizzled with local honey or cane molasses
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish shows Cordoba's Moorish heritage - the sweet-savory combination is quintessentially Arabic. During the 8th-10th centuries when Cordoba was the capital of the Umayyad Caliphate, it was Western Europe's largest, most cultured city. The Moors brought eggplants and honey-drizzling traditions that survive today.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tapas bars throughout Cordoba, especially in the Jewish Quarter (Juder铆a)

signature_drinks.name: Montilla-Moriles Wine
signature_drinks.description: Sherry-style wine from nearby Montilla region - dry, crisp, slightly nutty
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Cordoba's local wine comes from Montilla-Moriles DO, made like sherry but from Pedro Xim茅nez grapes. Locals drink the dry fino style chilled as an aperitif with tapas, especially olives and jam贸n. During Feria de C贸rdoba (May fair), everyone drinks it at the casetas (festival tents) while dancing sevillanas.

signature_drinks.name: Rebujito
signature_drinks.description: Mix of Montilla-Moriles sherry and lemon soda (Sprite or 7-Up) - refreshing, slightly sweet, dangerously easy to drink
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The official drink of Andalusian fairs. During Feria de C贸rdoba, rebujito flows in plastic cups from morning to dawn. It's deceptively strong - the sweet soda masks the alcohol. Locals warn tourists: 'Rebujito makes you dance like a pro, then fall like a fool.'
